title: Case Study: Chronic Achilles Tendinopathy in a Marathon Runner
clinical_history: Mark L., a 38-year-old competitive marathon runner, presents with a 3-month history of gradually worsening pain and stiffness in his right Achilles tendon. Symptoms began after increasing his weekly running mileage in preparation for a marathon. He reports initial morning stiffness that improves after a few steps, but the pain intensifies during the later stages of his runs, especially when training on hilly terrain. Mark denies any specific injury but recalls minor discomfort after a sprint session. Over time, he noticed swelling and occasional crepitus along the tendon. He is particularly concerned about decreased push-off power and mild limping after long runs. Mark has started skipping training sessions and is frustrated by his slow recovery.

nprs.affected_area: Achilles tendon (distal third, midline posterior aspect of right ankle)

aggrevating_factors: Running, particularly uphill, speedwork, prolonged walking, and climbing stairs. Morning activities and resuming movement after sitting for extended periods.
picture: Clinical photos would reveal localized swelling and mild thickening along the distal Achilles tendon, with possible palpable nodularity and mild erythema.
easing_factors: Relative rest, ice application, eccentric calf exercises, use of heel lifts in shoes, and short-term reduction in running volume.
past_history: No previous history of Achilles tendon injury. Minor lateral ankle sprain two years ago; recovered fully. History of mild plantar fasciitis last year, resolved with physiotherapy.
medical_history: Fit and healthy, no chronic illnesses. Non-smoker, occasional alcohol intake.
medications: PRN ibuprofen after runs (not taken daily). Using topical diclofenac gel.
personal_history: Works as an IT consultant with a mostly sedentary daytime routine. Runs 5-6 days per week (40-60 km total). Married, two young children. Admits to feeling stressed balancing family, work, and training commitments.
imaging: Ultrasound: Hypoechoic changes and thickening of the midportion of the Achilles tendon, minimal neovascularization, no frank tear detected. No calcifications or embedded foreign bodies observed.
